Problem:
Consider a physical system where the temperature change over time is modeled by the differential equation \\(dT/dt = kT\\), where k is a temperature-dependent conductivity coefficient. We investigate the effect of a transformation defined by the function \\( f(T) = T^2 \\) applied at different times.

If \\( f(T) \\) which squares the temperature T is applied at time t = 0, and then the system is allowed to evolve under \\(dT/dt = kT\\) without further intervention, will the temperature \\( T(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( T_0 \\), the initial temperature, was directly evolved to t = T under \\(dT/dt = kT\\)?
Explanation: Applying the function \\( f(T) = T^2 \\) at the initial stage changes the starting temperature to \\( T_0^2 \\). Since the rate of change of temperature is proportional to the temperature itself, the squared initial condition accelerates the temperature increase, diverging significantly from the trajectory when started at \\( T_0 \\) under \\(dT/dt = kT\\).
